awd_titl_txt: CIF21 DIBBs: PD: Cyberinfrastructure Tools for Precision Agriculture in the 21st Century
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary project applies computer science approaches and computational resources to large multidimensional environmental datasets, and synthesizes this information into finer resolution, spatially explicit products that can be systematically analyzed with other variables.  The main emphasis is ecoinformatics, a branch of informatics that analyzes ecological and environmental science variables such as information on landscapes, soils, climate, organisms, and ecosystems.  The project focuses on synthesis/computational approaches for producing high-resolution soil moisture datasets, and the pilot application is precision agriculture. The effort combines analytical geospatial approaches, machine learning methods, and high performance computing (HPC) techniques to build cyberinfrastructure tools that can transform how ecoinformatics data is analyzed.

The investigators build upon publicly available data collections (soil moisture datasets, soil properties datasets, and topography datasets) to develop: (1) tools based on machine-learning techniques to downscale coarse-grained data to fine-grained datasets of soil moisture information; (2) tools based on HPC techniques to estimate the degree of confidence and the probabilities associated with the temporal intervals within which soil-moisture-base changes, trends, and patterns occur; and (3) data- and user- interfaces integrating data preprocessing to deal with data heterogeneity and inaccuracy, containerized environments to assure portability, and modeling techniques to represent temporal and spatial patterns of soil moisture dynamics. The tools will inform precision agriculture through the generation and use of unique information on soil moisture for the coterminous United States.  Accessibility for field practitioners (e.g., local soil moisture information) is made possible through lightweight virtualization, mobile devices, and web applications.
	
This award by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the Division of Earth Sciences within the NSF Directorate for Geosciences.

por.por_cntn:
Soil moisture is an important parameter that regulates various ecosystem processes and has important implications for agriculture, climate change models and the prevention of natural disasters (e.g., floods, fires, droughts). Field information on soil moisture is obtained by in-situ soil sensors; however, these instruments do not provide the sufficient spatial coverage necessary in many applications. The combination of active and passive remote sensors on-board satellite platforms provides information on soil moisture over large areas, which helps to incorporate this information in large-area studies. However, the coarse resolution of the available products (around 36 to 9 km spatial resolution) represents a challenge in incorporating soil moisture information in applications that require higher spatial resolution. 

This project addresses the pressing need in providing soil moisture information in finer spatial detail over large areas. The solution is a software workflow called SOMOPSIE (a SOil MOisture SPatial Inference Engine) which uses machine learning techniques and environmental variables (e.g., topographic features) to generate soil moisture estimates at a user-defined, finer spatial resolution (i.e., increased granularity).  

SOMOSPIE was used to generate multiple open-access soil moisture datasets over the duration of the project; the datasets were released and are available to the scientific community in the HydroShare repository for use in diverse research domains including precision agriculture, climate modeling, and wildfire simulations. Predicted areas in the datasets includes the Midwest of the USA covering the state of Oklahoma and surrounding areas, a region in the West of the USA comprising areas between the Central valley in California, the southern portion of the Rocky Mountains and parts of the Nevada desert, the entire North America Continent, areas with heterogeneous environmental and climate gradients (i.e., geographical extent of countries such as Mexico, Canada and Australia), tropical areas with low available satellite data, among others. The SOMOPSIE software is open-source and can be downloaded by users through the project portal for the generation of new datasets at a desired resolution down to 1m x 1m grids. To assure portability across platforms, SOMOSPIE is available to run on high performance computing platforms, constrainarized environments using Singularity and Docker, and commercial Cloud.

The use of SOMPSPIE for studying trends of soil moisture reveals consistent soil moisture decline at the global scale. These soil moisture trends bring potential implications in the calibration of future projections of the water cycle, in identifying regions of strong land–atmosphere coupling, and in quantifying the contribution of soil moisture for land-surface models. The negative soil moisture trends found in the project results are consistent with recent soil moisture monitoring efforts. Soil moisture decline can be intensified by land warming, land use change, agricultural practices, or transformations to vegetation cover that directly affect primary productivity, evapotranspiration rates and drought. 

Contiguous information of soil moisture trends is increasingly needed for quantifying the consequences of soil moisture decline in ecosystems processes such as soil respiration. Project results complement existing soil moisture datasets as they identify soil moisture decline across a broad and diverse set of regions such as the Congo region or the Amazon basin. Further studies are needed to fully interpret the influence of surface or deeper soil moisture on ecological processes.
